messageBody:
I haven’t really thought this through (so ignore me if I’m missing something that should be obvious), but since JUnit now identifies test classes with attributes, would there be an advantage to having two different types of test classes (i.e. two different attributes): one for test classes that behave as they do now and one for test classes that keep the same instance for all tests? Then the developer can choose the attribute that best fits the kinds of tests that will go there? Or does that open the door too wide for misuse?

..David..


From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Cédric Beust ?
Sent: Thursday, October 23, 2008 12:09 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] @Before vs constructor


On Thu, Oct 23, 2008 at 10:50 AM, Joakim Ohlrogge
<joakim.ohlrogge@...<mailto:joakim.ohlrogge%40gmail.com>> wrote:
>
> Ok, I'm not currently doing that. I can see how maintaining expensive
> state can be useful in tests that are less of "unit tests", something
> that I would not mind if JUnit allowed but not at the expense of it's
> core which is unit-testing. Hence my resistance to giving up on
> "default isolation" in JUnit.

I certainly agree that this should remain the default in JUnit, I'm
just happy to see the alternative being considered as an option.

> In fact I remember strongly disagreeing with the reasons you give for
> creating TestNG: "I started TestNG out of frustration for some JUnit
> deficiencies..." where the examples you give relate to this thread.
> Since I found those deficeincies quite useful I did not find TestNG
> that interesting.
>
> For my style of testing default isolation gives me one thing less to
> think about and for your style it causes trouble. Obviously there are
> different opinions on the subject and I think that is a good thing
> (and a good thing that there are different frameworks to choose from).

Yes, this need (expensive state, sharing state, maintaining states for
dependent test methods, etc...) is more necessary in non-unit tests,
so I agree that it falls outside JUnit's scope. A lot of people use
JUnit to do more than unit testing, though...

--
Cédric
